chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Suspected dementia
chapter.summary: Covers when to refer a person with suspected dementia for specialist investigation and management.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 30 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Follow up of confirmed dementia in primary care

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected dementia?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange admission for people with suspected dementia if:
    • They are severely disturbed and admission is needed to ensure the health and safety of the person and/or the safety of others. Detention under the Mental Health Act (1983) may be needed.
      • For further information, see the section on the Mental Health Act (1983) in the CKS topic on Self-harm.
    • Assessment in primary care is not appropriate, for example, if the person has complex physical and psychiatric problems.
  • Refer to specialist psychiatry or neurology services (with urgency depending on clinical judgement), people with suspected dementia who:
    • Are likely to have a genetic cause for their dementia, such as familial autosomal dominant Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, or Huntington's disease. If a genetic cause of dementia is confirmed, unaffected relatives of the person should be referred for genetic counselling.
    • Have learning difficulties.
    • Are younger than 65 years of age.
    • Have focal neurological signs on examination.
    • Have rapid cognitive decline.
  • Refer all other people with suspected dementia or mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to a memory assessment service (such as memory clinic or the community mental health team) for further specialist assessment and management.
    • If mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is diagnosed:
      • Discuss the diagnosis without provoking undue anxiety.
      • Arrange regular follow up visits (for example every 6 months) to monitor possible progression of cognitive deficit. If symptoms worsen re-refer to the mental health team.
      • Suggest healthy brain activities such as regular exercise, word games, and socialization.
    • If dementia is diagnosed, see the section on follow up of confirmed dementia in primary care for more information.
  • Discuss the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) regulations on driving and cognitive impairment.
  • Treat any identified, modifiable risk factors for cognitive impairment (such as excess alcohol intake, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obesity and smoking) where possible.
    • For further information, see the CKS topics on Alcohol - problem drinking, CVD risk assessment and management, Diabetes - type 1, Diabetes - type 2, Hypertension - not diabetic, Obesity, and Smoking cessation.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Which specialist investigations are available?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Specialist investigations for suspected dementia [NICE, 2006; Iliffe, 2009; GPAC, 2014]:
    • Should include structural imaging (magnetic resonance imaging [MRI] or occasionally computed tomography [CT] scan) to:
      • Exclude non-dementia cerebral pathology such as normal pressure hydrocephalus.
      • Identify dementia subtype.
    • May also include [NICE, 2006; Rossor, 2010; Robinson, 2015]:
      • HMPAO SPECT and FDG PET as second line investigations if diagnosis or subtype is unclear.
      • (FP-CIT) SPECT where a potential diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is in doubt.
      • Cerebrospinal fluid examination to exclude inflammatory, infective, or malignant causes of dementia, in cases where dementia is rapidly progressive, the presentation is unusual, or the person is younger than 55 years of age.
      • Electroencephalography if a diagnosis of delirium, frontotemporal dementia, or Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease is suspected, or in the assessment of associated seizure disorder in people with dementia.
      • Brain biopsy in highly selected people whose dementia is thought to be due to a potentially reversible condition (such as cerebral vasculitis) that cannot be diagnosed in another way.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Information on driving and cognitive impairment
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The DVLA states that for mild cognitive impairment (not mild dementia) with [DVLA, 2016]:
    • No likely driving impairment — group 1 (car and motorcycle) and group 2 (bus and lorry) licence holders may drive and need not notify the DVLA. 
    • Possible driving impairment — group 1 and group 2 license holders must not drive and must notify the DVLA. Licensing will be considered individually following medical enquiries.
  • When dementia is diagnosed, the person is legally required to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) [DVLA, 2016].
    • The DVLA states that for dementia and/or any organic syndrome affecting cognitive functioning:
      • Group 1 (car and motorcycle) license holders may be able to drive but must notify the DVLA, the decision on licensing is usually based on medical reports. Poor short-term memory, disorientation, and lack of insight and judgement almost certainly mean no fitness to drive. The variable presentation and rate of progression is acknowledged. Disorders of attention will also cause impairment. In early dementia, when sufficient skills are retained and progression is slow, a licence may be issued subject to annual review. A formal driving assessment may be necessary. 
      • Group 2 (bus and lorry) — license holders must not drive and must notify the DVLA. Licensing will be refused or revoked.
  • For complete and up to date guidance on driving and cognitive impairment, see the DVLA document 'Assessing fitness to drive - a guide for medical professionals'.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to manage suspected dementia are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Dementia: supporting people with dementia and their carers in health and social care (CG42) [NICE, 2006] and Dementia, disability and frailty in later life – mid-life approaches to delay or prevent onset [NICE, 2015a], the Guidelines and Protocols Advisory Committee (GPAC) guideline Cognitive impairment: recognition, diagnosis and management in primary care [GPAC, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles on dementia [Villars, 2010; Robinson, 2015].

  • NICE recommends that memory assessment services (such as memory assessment clinics or the community mental health team) should be the single point of referral for all people with suspected dementia and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) [NICE, 2006]. 
    • Diagnosis of subtype of dementia can only be made by healthcare professionals with expertise in this area such as elderly care psychiatrists [NICE, 2006].
    • For people with MCI, prompt referral will help identify dementia early. Half of people with MCI will later develop dementia.
  • Expert opinion in review articles on dementia is that referral for subtyping of dementia is important as the management and prognosis for each subtype is different [Iliffe, 2009; Robinson, 2015].
